newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish meat firm Kolo eyes listing in late '97.
newsitem.headline: Polish meat firm Kolo eyes listing in late '97.

text.p: The Polish meat producer Zaklady Miesne w Kole SA (Kolo), majority-owned by Sokolow SA, will likely enter the Warsaw bourse's main market at the end of 1997, Sokolow's deputy president said on Wednesday.

"We want to submit (Kolo's) issue prospectus to the Securities Commission by the end of June...and I think we should put the firm on the main market no sooner than the end of 1997," Krzysztof Lewczuk told Reuters.
He said the firm's planned public offering would not be large and would be carried out with the intent to disperse the firm's ownership structure, as required by Polish law.
Kolo currently has 3.2 million shares, with a 50.8-percent stake held by meat processing firm Sokolow and 14.1 percent by an employee-controlled firm.
The state treasury holds a 35.2-percent stake.

Kolo's trade director told Reuters late last year that the company's public offer would amount to about eight million zlotys. The firm expects to net five million zlotys this year on 276.7 million zlotys in sales.
